ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: developed my reporting skills, seeking out sources, writing ledes and nut graphs

Education policy (a small bit), journalism, journalism faux pas, editing skills/how to give feedback, learned a lot about different controversies in journalism and things that bother editors/writers/things that you're not supposed to do. It's really not a course about education policy, even though that's the focus. It's really more about journalism and techniques and the business.
Understanding of journalism and the education beat. Journalistic writing style.
Basic journalism skills, discussion of education journalism

I developed in-depth knowledge of journalistic practices and the present-day problems facing education. I have limited experience with journalism, and I felt like my writing ability and confidence increased in this class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: guest speakers, clear feedback, timely discussions, variety of assignments; weaknesses: class discussions could be either slow or tense

Didn't love the way the professor taught. Professor Karr just talked at us, asked some questions that didn't make sense with what we were learning. The premise of the course is really promising but I just think more discussion among classmates would improve it greatly. We barely got to talk or share our opinions, unless it was something controversial that she asked us about. The readings were great.

Strengths: The guest speakers!! professionals in the field who were so generous with their time, advice, and honestly. 

Weaknesses: The professor.

Strengths: Really good feedback systems 
Weaknesses: Readings were interesting but wish we could have dug more deeply into them

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think this is a class that you get out as much as you put in. I personally learned a lot, but I don't know if it's for everyone. Definitely for those interested in journalism or who want to learn more about covering education

I heard a rumor that Emmanuel Felton might teach this class in the future since Professor Karr is retiring and if that's true, please take it! He was a guest speaker of ours and he was excellent!!! Had so many great things to say about writing about race, and also just in general he was lovely and very smart about journalism/life.
this was Jane's last year so if this is offered again with a different professor, I suggest taking it.
Yes definitely, it's a great class to improve your writing skills and learn about a new area of journalism

I would, but hesitantly. The assignments and readings are interesting, and youll definitely end up a better writer because of it. That being said, Jane is a force to be reckoned with, and not necessarily in a good way. Sometimes, her playing devils advocate became insensitive and her criticism was flat out insulting. If you want to take this class, be aware that you might have to put up with some uncomfortable (and sometimes extremely ignorant) conversations.
